The Cit√© Internationale Universitaire de Paris is a remarkable haven for students from diverse corners of the globe, offering a unique and enriching living experience. Nestled in the heart of Paris, this international residential campus is more than just accommodation; it's a vibrant community that fosters cultural exchange, academic growth, and lifelong connections.  One of the standout features of the Cit√© Internationale is its architectural diversity. Each pavilion reflects the distinct cultural identity of its residents, creating a miniaturized global village within the city. The charming blend of architectural styles serves as a constant reminder of the rich cultural tapestry represented by students from around the world.  The cite's inclusive atmosphere is a catalyst for meaningful cross-cultural interactions. With communal spaces, shared kitchens, and numerous events organized throughout the year, residents have ample opportunities to forge friendships and exchange ideas with peers from various backgrounds. The result is a unique microcosm where diverse perspectives converge, contributing to a truly global educational experience.  The Cit√© Internationale's commitment to academic excellence is reflected in its state-of-the-art facilities, including well-equipped libraries, study rooms, and collaborative spaces. The presence of numerous international institutions on the campus further enhances the academic environment, offering students a chance to engage with a broad spectrum of disciplines and intellectual pursuits.  Beyond academics, the Cit√© Internationale prioritizes the well-being of its residents. The lush green spaces, recreational facilities, and cultural events organized on-site create a holistic environment that nurtures both personal and academic growth. The focus on a balanced lifestyle fosters a sense of belonging and support crucial for students navigating the challenges of studying in a foreign country.

Indeed, when you get here, you get into different cities of culture and where everyone lives in peace, and sometimes various cultural events of foreign countries take place in houses and you can get to know different cultures and interests and it‚Äôs awesome experience ! Fabulous ! Stunning !

We are managing the major Data Management Annual meeting there every years and we really enjoy it! It is a great place with a very historical architecture. If you need to manage a large event in Paris with a pretty technical background, then this is the place!!

A community like no other. A philanthropist started this community of international residence to students from all over the world. The place houses 6000 students in 40 houses across a vast space with a great park in the middle. Houses are built by support of NGOs and philanthropists and named after them or their countries. Amazing and diverse architecture surrounded by slot of greenery and car free spaces.

This is for the Maison Heinrich- Heine:  The building is very well equipped, with a cafe, large library (great place to study) and very kind staff. Unfortunately, it's really a place for undergraduate level students, as the ambience is more akin to a dorm than a place to truly live. The noise level is outrageous, with people having parties or being inconsiderate with their talking/ music in the hallways. The walls are so thin that I can hear someone cough in the room next door, so you can only imagine how bad it is when someone has a few guests! The cleanliness of the common areas leaves much to be desired, as many of the residents seem incapable of living as adults and cleaning up after themselves. The kitchen on my floor was always filthy, and the Maison doesn't supply dish liquid or sponges :/ The toilet and showers were also pretty gross, especially over the weekend. It reminded me of elementary school, where people weren't 100% used to using the toilet on their own. Yet these are "adults", young, but still adults.  The price was 410 for younger than 29 and 460 for older, which isn't bad for Paris, but I expect to live comfortably (sanitary conditions and no excessive noise) for that amount. The house is also quite far in the back of campus, which means it takes almost 10 minutes to get to the RER station on foot. When the weather is bad (there is only 1 paved road) it can be a really messy and long walk.  Overall, it's better than being homeless (and there is maid service), but having to wear ear plugs all the time to just study or read in my room, isn't any way to live.
Beautiful place to live. You interact with different people from around the world. The trees are amazing. The vibe feels good here. All the houses are nice

I love this place, if you're coming as an student to live in Paris try to get a place here, it is simply beautiful with the gardens and each country has its house that, and it is easier if you apply to the house of your nationality (if there is one) Mexico has one! So don't hesitate to contact them.

Best place to have a student experience in Paris. The environment is very international. Each building is a "house" that "belongs" to a different country.  So many activities to take part in, lots of clubs and student associations.  The atmosphere is very friendly, and the spaces are vast and filled with greenery. Probably the only place inside Metropolitan Paris where one can have a truly international "University" experience.
Used to live here. Beautiful park around, tennis courts available, interesting architecture of the houses. However, it can have a wired vibe. Was happy to move out.

The establishment is well organized and the community is fantastic.  On the other hand, the administration is less interested in promoting the community, and has recently started adding additional charges and limiting flexibility in social events.

Wonderful park area in the summer, and mostly comfortable dorms. For an extended stay in Paris as a student, this is perfect. It's not in the heart of Paris obviously, but a quick metro ride will get you to the latin quarter‚Äîand you won't even have to switch lines to do it.

If already been to Paris many times you can choose to come here to have a different walk and a different view of the city. Its buildings date mostly from the 1920s and it was built to promote students coming to Paris to Study. Great place for a relaxed walk or for a Picnic in the central Garden.

One of the must see places in Paris. It is a wonderful initiative from the French, to provide accommodation to international students and researchers in one big campus. It is extremely international and allows people to blend into the french system without having to worry about the language. It also provides a great cultural exchange and exchange of ideas as students of multiple facets get to live under one roof
Beautiful place. The grand Pelouse is the perfect place to spend the weekend if sunny. Lots of activities for the residents during the year and good sport installations.

Very disorganised and a very primitive method of managing the people. Understaffed and 3 check points before you can actually speak to someone that can help you. No roof outside for people waiting (can be up to several hours). It surprises me how a place like this has remained so inefficient. I have been here 4 times for one application process. End up just standing here to get another rendez vous for another day so they cant finish your application even if its possible. Honestly upgrade these premises and employ more staff and desks. Its straightfoward.
Beautiful domain with about 40 different buildings all in the style of their home country. Two restaurants, plenty of sport facilities and great outdoor area.
Nice building with a communal restroom on the main level. Also seemed like a very popular spot for students at lunch time as they lined up for what I guess was a cafeteria style meal service.
